entry.content:
English Thinking

5 ways to think in English|Stop translating in your head

  • Change language of electronic devices and apps into English
  • Write lists in English
    • to-do lists
    • shopping lists
  • Describe what you see in English in your head
  • Imagine sentences that you might use in a conversation
  • Think of all the things you did that day in English befor you go to bed

How to learn anything faster

9 tips

  • Sharpen the axe

If you gave me six hours to chop down a tree, I would spend the first hour sharpening the axe.

——Abraham Lincoln

  • Use crutches to optimise your focus
    • five-minute rule: we just have to convince ourselves that we’re just gonna do the thing for five minutes
    • chuck your phone away
  • Find opportunities for immersion
    • learn the skill by using it as much as possible
  • Figure out what your weak links are
    • ask yourself, if the exam were tomorrow, what topic would I be the least happy, or the most pissed off about?
  • Test yourself
  • Get intense feedback as often as possible and as quickly as possible
  • Overlearn
    • learn not only what or how to do, but also why to do
  • Spacing
  • Teach what you are trying to learn

Feynman Technique

  1. Fully understand the complex topic first: Don’t begin the learning process by explaining it before you actually understand it. Retention methods such as Feynman technique, active-recall and spaced repetition are for solidifying information that you already understand. Trying to solidify an information before you understand it might end up encoding wrong interpretation of a topic.

  2. Consolidate the information concisely onto a flashcard/some other place for long term retention: Once we really understand a topic to be able to explain the core principles without having to use jargon, we should hold onto that understanding. Unfortunately, a large portion of that information that we just gathered is lost within first 48 hours after learning. So note it down somewhere before you lose it. Optimize for spaced-repetition for next sessions.

  3. Don’t write notes on notes: Life is short.

  4. Choose your topics carefully: Not everything that you study suits this technique. Usually abstract complex ideas are best understood by Feynman technique but ideas that are evidence-based/observational might not really be suited for this.

  5. Actually put the time and effort: Once you have selected the correct set of topics, make sure you actually spend the time and effort to go through the entirety of the techniques. Feynman technique is great for having a basic framework of the topic inside your head with the details chopped off. It’s important to get a very clear picture of the basics in your head right - the details can be filled in later.

  6. Avoid jargon and complexity. The simpler the explanation, the more likely you are to remember it.

  7. Use it for real: perfectly suitable for weekly tech-talks/lectures/paper-reading sessions.

  8. Simplify your explanation so that YOU understand it. As long as the explanation is not simple enough for YOU to understand, spend more hours to break it down to basic, bare-bone, core ideas.

How to build good study habits

“Humans are creatures of habit.” According to researchers, almost 40% to 95% of our total behavior pattern is driven by habits, which are subconscious acts that we tend to repeat in certain situations. So, if you can develop good habits, they’ll lead you to live a productive and satisfying life, no matter how small or insignificant they seem. Here’s a short, five-step formula that will help.

  • NO.5 Settle on the Habit
  • NO.4 Repeat Regularly
  • NO.3 Monitor Over the Long Term
  • NO.2 Make It Convenient
  • NO.1 Reward to Reinforce

Fail again, fail smarter

  1. Adopt a third-person perspective: soften negative emotional reactions, look at failure more objectively
  2. Offer advice to others who may be in the same position as us: force ourself to engage with our experience and what we have learned

数字通信系统

  • 为何在脉冲成型之前需要进行上采样？
    原因：为了在脉冲成型阶段按符号间隔TpT_pTp​来间隔升余弦波形。考虑如下脉冲成型后的信号，其中p(t)p(t)p(t)为升余弦脉冲，aka_kak​为发送符号：

s(t)=∑kakp(t−kTp)=∑kp(k)∗akδ(t−kTp)s(t)=\sum_{k}a_kp(t-kT_p)=\sum_{k}p(k)*a_k\delta(t-kT_p) s(t)=k∑​ak​p(t−kTp​)=k∑​p(k)∗ak​δ(t−kTp​)

如果想在Matlab中以离散时间模拟这一过程，需在脉冲成型前通过内插使得符号率rsymr_{sym}rsym​和后面的采样频率fsf_sfs​相匹配，即相邻符号间内插sps-1个0，其中每个符号的采样点数sps=fs/rsymsps=f_s/r_{sym}sps=fs​/rsym​。

  • 为何在数字系统中以Eb/N0E_b/N_0Eb​/N0​为度量指标？
    原因：模拟通信中模拟信号归类为功率信号，即平均功率有限能量无穷的信号，因此功率对于模拟信号是一个更有用的参数，即S/N。而数字通信系统采用时间长度为码元间隔TsT_sTs​的波形来发送和接受码元。每个码元的平均功率（在整个时间轴上取平均）为0，所以不能用功率描述数字信号。而码元能量是一个能在时间窗口内度量信号的测度的参数。数字信号波形包含比特信息，故用比特信噪比Eb/N0E_b/N_0Eb​/N0​描述最为合适。

换算关系：

  • Es/N0=(Tsym/Tsamp)∗SNRE_s/N_0=(T_{sym}/T_{samp})*SNREs​/N0​=(Tsym​/Tsamp​)∗SNR,由SN=EsRsN0W\frac{S}{N}=\frac{E_sR_s}{N_0W}NS​=N0​WEs​Rs​​可推知,其中W一般用采样率fsf_sfs​代替,可以认为高斯白噪声信道中采样率以下的噪声都被采进来了。
  • Es/N0=Eb/N0+10log⁡10kE_s/N_0=E_b/N_0 + 10\log_{10}{k}Es​/N0​=Eb​/N0​+10log10​k in dB, 其中k表示每符号比特数，由编码规则和调制方式共同决定。例如（7，4）汉明码+BPSK，1个符号有1个信道比特，1个信道比特有4/7个信息比特，故k=47log22k=\frac{4}{7}log_{2}{2}k=74​log2​2；（7，4）汉明码+QPSK，1个符号有2个信道比特，1个信道比特有4/7个信息比特，故k=47log24k=\frac{4}{7}log_{2}{4}k=74​log2​4。
  • 对于实信号，Es/N0=0.5∗(Tsym/Tsamp)∗SNRE_s/N_0=0.5*(T_{sym}/T_{samp})*SNREs​/N0​=0.5∗(Tsym​/Tsamp​)∗SNR,这是由于实信号的高斯白噪声功率谱为N02\frac{N_0}{2}2N0​​,复信号的高斯白噪声功率谱为N0N_0N0​.
